HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 8, 1924

A FULL-TIME ALUMNI SECRETARY
President Goodnow's statement that "we shall have to face the
coming year with the expectation of a deficit in current operation"
does not seem to encourage any additional outlay of money. Yet
we cannot help but suggest that the employment of a full-time
Alumni Secretary would prove an advantageous and, eventually, a
profitable investment.
At other colleges and universities, alumni have been formed into
influential and powerful groups and have proved to be invaluable
assets in the fields of expansion and general finance. At Hopkins,
however, alumni support has always been, to a large extent, unorganized and, therefore, comparatively ineffectual. This state of affairs
at Homewood may be partly due to the fact that Johns Hopkins is a
young institution. We feel, however, that a capable man, able to
devote all of his time to organization, will find it possible to weld
the alumni into a compact and practicable body. The present Alumni
Secretary, although obviously hampered by lack of funds and by
duties resulting from his position of Associate Professor, has made
an excellent start. Time and application are necessary for further

There is plenty of work that an Alumni Secretary could do. Can
we afford one, Mr. Trustee?

STAMPS WILL DO IT
Success often leads to over-confidence. With this thought in
mind we should shudder as we note on the campus the apparent
inertia and indifference regarding 1924 June Week. The first June
Week, managed by the Class of 1923 with the co-operation of the
undergraduate body, was a success far beyond the hopes of its most
optimistic supporters. We fear that Hopkins, remembering only
the result and forgetting the labor involved, is taking further good
fortune for granted.
And in all fairness we cannot but say that this inertia is caused
by the inactivity of the Senior Class and, especially, of the June
Week Committee. Recently, an excellent and practical plan of stampselling was devised. To the writer's knowledge, however, the stamps
have only been placed on sale upon one occasion, and, then, most' of
the seniors who had charge of the work expected lowerclassmen
to flock around them with their money.
In the way of constructive criticism, we would suggest that
weekly "Tag Days," similar to those of last year, be inaugurated.
Tags, then, could be given in addition to the stamps and the desire
of conformity will cause many men who do not expect to attend
the series of affairs to part with a small amount of change. There
are many who will willingly support June Week if only given an
opportunity.
June Week is not "going across' on its own volition. It needs
a representative, well-organized, and hard-working committee; it
needs more than anything else the support of the undergraduate body.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 8, 1924

A FULL-TIME ALUMNI SECRETARY
President Goodnow's statement that "we shall have to face the
coming year with the expectation of a deficit in current operation"
does not seem to encourage any additional outlay of money. Yet
we cannot help but suggest that the employment of a full-time
Alumni Secretary would prove an advantageous and, eventually, a
profitable investment.
At other colleges and universities, alumni have been formed into
influential and powerful groups and have proved to be invaluable
assets in the fields of expansion and general finance. At Hopkins,
however, alumni support has always been, to a large extent, unorganized and, therefore, comparatively ineffectual. This state of affairs
at Homewood may be partly due to the fact that Johns Hopkins is a
young institution. We feel, however, that a capable man, able to
devote all of his time to organization, will find it possible to weld
the alumni into a compact and practicable body. The present Alumni
Secretary, although obviously hampered by lack of funds and by
duties resulting from his position of Associate Professor, has made
an excellent start. Time and application are necessary for further

STAMPS WILL DO IT
Success often leads to over-confidence. With this thought in
mind we should shudder as we note on the campus the apparent
inertia and indifference regarding 1924 June Week. The first June
Week, managed by the Class of 1923 with the co-operation of the
undergraduate body, was a success far beyond the hopes of its most
optimistic supporters. We fear that Hopkins, remembering only
the result and forgetting the labor involved, is taking further good
fortune for granted.
And in all fairness we cannot but say that this inertia is caused
by the inactivity of the Senior Class and, especially, of the June
Week Committee. Recently, an excellent and practical plan of stampselling was devised. To the writer's knowledge, however, the stamps
have only been placed on sale upon one occasion, and, then, most' of
the seniors who had charge of the work expected lowerclassmen
to flock around them with their money.
In the way of constructive criticism, we would suggest that
weekly "Tag Days," similar to those of last year, be inaugurated.
Tags, then, could be given in addition to the stamps and the desire
of conformity will cause many men who do not expect to attend
the series of affairs to part with a small amount of change. There
are many who will willingly support June Week if only given an
opportunity.
June Week is not "going across' on its own volition. It needs
a representative, well-organized, and hard-working committee; it
needs more than anything else the support of the undergraduate body.
